articles.headline: Wealthy Reduce Buying in a Blow to the Recovery
articles.snippet: The cautious attitude stems from concerns about global instability and the recent volatility of stocks.
articles.abstract: The cautious attitude stems from concerns about global instability and the recent volatility of stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic recovery has been helped in large part by the spending of the most affluent. Now, even the rich appear to be tightening their belts.

articles.headline: Apple Goes on the Offensive
articles.snippet: Steven P. Jobs acknowledged some problems with the iPhone 4’s antenna, but said they had been widely exaggerated.
articles.abstract: Steven P. Jobs acknowledged some problems with the iPhone 4’s antenna, but said they had been widely exaggerated.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Many expected a mea culpa from Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive. Instead, he turned the iPhone 4’s antenna problems into a marketing event on Friday.

articles.headline: 3 Auto Dealer Tactics the Overhaul Missed
articles.snippet: The financial regulation bill fails to provide oversight of some of the more troublesome loan practices of auto dealers.
articles.abstract: The financial regulation bill fails to provide oversight of some of the more troublesome loan practices of auto dealers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometime next week, President Obama will finally sign a financial reform bill. Plenty of banks will have to deal with messy new rules, but one big winner in the “spare me from further regulation” sweepstakes was auto dealers.

articles.headline: A.I.G. to Pay $725 Million in Ohio Case
articles.snippet: The settlement would resolve claims of fraud laid out in a class-action suit led by three Ohio pension funds.
articles.abstract: The settlement would resolve claims of fraud laid out in a class-action suit led by three Ohio pension funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group, once the nation’s largest insurance group before it nearly collapsed in 2008, has agreed to pay $725 million to three Ohio pension funds to settle six-year-old claims of accounting fraud, stock manipulation and bid-rigging.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Iran’s President Renews Pressure on Conservatives
articles.snippet: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s warning that “the regime has only one party” provoked outrage from his conservative rivals.
articles.abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s warning that “the regime has only one party” provoked outrage from his conservative rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Having successfully suppressed the opposition uprising that followed last summer’s disputed presidential election, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his supporters are now renewing their efforts to marginalize another rival group — Iran’s traditional conservatives.
articles.byline: By William Yong and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Bangladesh, With Low Pay, Moves In on China
articles.snippet: As costs have risen in China, it is losing work to countries like Bangladesh for cheaper, labor-intensive goods.
articles.abstract: As costs have risen in China, it is losing work to countries like Bangladesh for cheaper, labor-intensive goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZIPUR, Bangladesh  The eight-lane highway leading from the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, narrows repeatedly as it approaches this town about 30 miles north, eventually depositing cars onto a muddy, potholed lane bordered by mangroves and small shops.

articles.headline: Was Steinbrenner Just Lucky?
articles.snippet: George Steinbrenner bought the Yankees for $10 million and turned the team into a financial powerhouse. But what if the circumstances had been different?
articles.abstract: George Steinbrenner bought the Yankees for $10 million and turned the team into a financial powerhouse. But what if the circumstances had been different?
articles.lead_paragraph: Before he bought the New York Yankees, George Steinbrenner tried to buy the Cleveland Indians.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Split Reported on Goldman
articles.snippet: The commissioners split along party lines about whether to approve a $550 million settlement to end a fraud inquiry.
articles.abstract: The commissioners split along party lines about whether to approve a $550 million settlement to end a fraud inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The commissioners of the Securities and Exchange Commission were divided on whether to approve the $550 million settlement with Goldman Sachs, which ended months of negotiations over a securities fraud case, people with knowledge of the vote said Friday.

articles.headline: Short List Emerges for Consumer Guardian
articles.snippet: The list of leading candidates to head the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has narrowed to three.
articles.abstract: The list of leading candidates to head the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has narrowed to three.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, savoring Congressional approval of a far-reaching financial regulation bill, now faces a crucial choice over who will lead the powerful new consumer guardian created by the legislation.

articles.headline: The Men Who Ended Goldman’s War
articles.snippet: For Robert Khuzami of the S.E.C. and Gregory Palm of Goldman Sachs, it was one of the cases that can define a career. Each side is claiming a victory.
articles.abstract: For Robert Khuzami of the S.E.C. and Gregory Palm of Goldman Sachs, it was one of the cases that can define a career. Each side is claiming a victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST Wednesday at around 3 p.m., the Securities and Exchange Commission and Goldman Sachs settled an epic, seismic battle  one waged over whether the storied investment bank defrauded investors in a transaction that regulators said Goldman had built to self-destruct.

articles.headline: Palin Wades Into Republican Midterm Primaries
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin is leaving a major footprint on the 2010 midterm elections, but it is less clear whether her endorsements are part of a strategy for the future.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin is leaving a major footprint on the 2010 midterm elections, but it is less clear whether her endorsements are part of a strategy for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga.  The latest candidate to win the most coveted Republican prize of the election year stood on the steps of a gazebo here and reminded voters of a new reason to support her in the crowded race for Georgia governor.

articles.headline: Factory Defies Sweatshop Label, but Can It Thrive?
articles.snippet: An American-owned apparel factory in the Dominican Republic has committed to pay a living wage — three times the average for the industry there.
articles.abstract: An American-owned apparel factory in the Dominican Republic has committed to pay a living wage — three times the average for the industry there.
articles.lead_paragraph: VILLA ALTAGRACIA, Dominican Republic

articles.headline: Unlikely Tutor Giving Military Afghan Advice
articles.snippet: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal found an ally in Greg Mortenson, the author of “Three Cups of Tea,” whose work had led to building schools in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal found an ally in Greg Mortenson, the author of “Three Cups of Tea,” whose work had led to building schools in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the frantic last hours of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s command in Afghanistan, when the world wondered what was racing through the general’s mind, he reached out to an unlikely corner of his life: the author of the book “Three Cups of Tea,” Greg Mortenson.

articles.headline: Holding Bankers’ Feet to the Fire
articles.snippet: The regulator who oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is moving aggressively to try to recover money from institutions that sold troubled loans to the two mortgage giants.
articles.abstract: The regulator who oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is moving aggressively to try to recover money from institutions that sold troubled loans to the two mortgage giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUDOS to the Federal Housing Finance Agency, overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the crippled mortgage finance giants. While some in Washington have continued to coddle the big banks even after they drove our economy into the ditch, this agency seems serious about recovering money for taxpayers by holding bad financial actors to account.

articles.headline: As Facebook Users Die, Ghosts Reach Out
articles.snippet: The world’s biggest social network has had trouble figuring out when one of its 500 million users has died.
articles.abstract: The world’s biggest social network has had trouble figuring out when one of its 500 million users has died.
articles.lead_paragraph: Courtney Purvin got a shock when she visited Facebook last month. The site was suggesting that she get back in touch with an old family friend who played piano at her wedding four years ago.

articles.headline: Insurers Push Plans That Limit Choice of Doctor
articles.snippet: As the White House begins to enact the new national health care law, the biggest insurers are promoting plans with lower premiums that allow fewer doctors and hospitals.
articles.abstract: As the White House begins to enact the new national health care law, the biggest insurers are promoting plans with lower premiums that allow fewer doctors and hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration begins to enact the new national health care law, the country’s biggest insurers are promoting affordable plans with reduced premiums that require participants to use a narrower selection of doctors or hospitals.

articles.headline: BP Hopes to Keep Well Closed, but Seep Is Detected
articles.snippet: The discovery of a seep suggests that the well could be damaged and that it may have to be reopened soon.
articles.abstract: The discovery of a seep suggests that the well could be damaged and that it may have to be reopened soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: After three days of encouraging pressure tests, a senior BP official said Sunday that the company’s recently capped well in the Gulf of Mexico was holding up and that BP now hoped to keep the well closed until it could be permanently plugged. But government officials were more skeptical and cited a new potential problem.

articles.headline: After Tumult, Debt Worries Ease in Europe
articles.snippet: Two months ago, Europe’s debt problems seemed grave enough to imperil the global economic recovery. Now, some investors are treating it as the crisis that wasn’t.
articles.abstract: Two months ago, Europe’s debt problems seemed grave enough to imperil the global economic recovery. Now, some investors are treating it as the crisis that wasn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just two months ago, Europe’s sovereign debt problems seemed grave enough to imperil the global economic recovery. Now, at least some investors are treating it as the crisis that wasn’t.

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Elite Pay Few Taxes, Widening Gap
articles.snippet: The lack of a workable tax system feeds an inequality in Pakistani society, and is helping an insurgency spread.
articles.abstract: The lack of a workable tax system feeds an inequality in Pakistani society, and is helping an insurgency spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Much of Pakistan’s capital city looks like a rich Los Angeles suburb. Shiny sport utility vehicles purr down gated driveways. Elegant multistory homes are tended by servants. Laundry is never hung out to dry.

articles.headline: After Training, Still Scrambling for Employment
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of Americans have enrolled in federally financed programs, but remain out of work.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Americans have enrolled in federally financed programs, but remain out of work.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what was beginning to feel like a previous life, Israel Valle had earned $18 an hour as an executive assistant to a designer at a prominent fashion label. Now, he was jobless and struggling to find work. He decided to invest in upgrading his skills.

articles.headline: Obama Wins Unlikely Allies in Immigration
articles.snippet: President Obama is gaining support among evangelical leaders who want a path to legalization for illegal immigrants.
articles.abstract: President Obama is gaining support among evangelical leaders who want a path to legalization for illegal immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when the prospects for immigration overhaul seem most dim, supporters have unleashed a secret weapon: a group of influential evangelical Christian leaders.

articles.headline: TARP Audit Questions Rush to Close Auto Dealers
articles.snippet: A report on the bailout of G.M. and Chrysler concluded that they needed to shut some dealerships but questioned their timetables.
articles.abstract: A report on the bailout of G.M. and Chrysler concluded that they needed to shut some dealerships but questioned their timetables.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  President Obama’s auto task force pressed General Motors and Chrysler to close scores of dealerships without adequately considering the jobs that would be lost or having a firm idea of the cost savings that would be achieved, an audit of the process has concluded.

articles.headline: French Heiress vs. Daughter and Political Intrigue
articles.snippet: A fierce family fight involving the heiress to the L’Oréal fortune has shaken the office of President Nicolas Sarkozy.
articles.abstract: A fierce family fight involving the heiress to the L’Oréal fortune has shaken the office of President Nicolas Sarkozy.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — An aging heiress. An angry daughter. A society photographer. A renegade butler and an embittered accountant. Secret tapes. A famous company with a nasty past and long political connections. An unpopular president and a cabinet minister with a taste for money, and tales of illegal cash donations in envelopes.

articles.headline: In a World of Online News, Burnout Starts Younger
articles.snippet: At Politico, the news can start in the darkness before dawn. And turnover can be high.
articles.abstract: At Politico, the news can start in the darkness before dawn. And turnover can be high.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va.  In most newsrooms, the joke would have been obvious.

articles.headline: Policing the Web’s Lurid Precincts
articles.snippet: Internet companies must screen content submitted by users, and the firms that sell the screening services are weighing the emotional toll on their workers.
articles.abstract: Internet companies must screen content submitted by users, and the firms that sell the screening services are weighing the emotional toll on their workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ricky Bess spends eight hours a day in front of a computer near Orlando, Fla., viewing some of the worst depravities harbored on the Internet. He has seen photographs of graphic gang killings, animal abuse and twisted forms of pornography. One recent sighting was a photo of two teenage boys gleefully pointing guns at another boy, who is crying.

articles.headline: Post-Mortem: No Hair Shirt for Steve Jobs
articles.snippet: Steve Jobs will be giving out bumpers and cases for the iPhone 4. And in case you missed it, he doesn’t exactly have a crush on reporters.
articles.abstract: Steve Jobs will be giving out bumpers and cases for the iPhone 4. And in case you missed it, he doesn’t exactly have a crush on reporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: By now, most people know what happens when your fingers come in contact with the lower left-hand corner of the iPhone 4 — are you there? — but it took the touch of an old-line, nontech tester of technology to get Apple to admit as much.

articles.headline: As Niche Gets Crowded, Studio Watches Its Back
articles.snippet: As an independent, DreamWorks Animation is facing challenges on many fronts as other studios dive into animation.
articles.abstract: As an independent, DreamWorks Animation is facing challenges on many fronts as other studios dive into animation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In April, Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chief executive of DreamWorks Animation, voiced public fury at Warner Brothers for having abruptly converted its “Clash of the Titans” into 3-D and releasing it a week after his company’s 3-D film, “How to Train Your Dragon.”
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply
